item.name: 007 James Bond: Live and Let Die
item.comment: Overall bland chase/gunfight game that doesn't offer much by way of interesting things to do. It should be more exciting given that it's based on a darn good movie boat chase.

item.name: 10 Days in Europe
item.comment: Probably good for educational purposes, but to me rather boring.

item.name: 1825 Unit 1
item.comment: I like a tight economic system -- heck, I love Age of Steam. But the limitations in this game are so ridiculously arbitrary. Why are there no shallow arcs with small stations? Why so few 5 trains? Why can't we sell stock directly to other players? The result feels unnecessarily constraining and scripted. A friend once commented that there is something fundamentally wrong with a game if it has money in both one and five hundred denominations, and that is true of this game, making the math involved mind-numbing and again, arbitrary. In our game, I came in second, and not even a distant second; everyone at the table was surprised, none more than me. I had no business finishing so well, and thus something, SOMETHING, must have been wrong.

item.name: 1955: The War of Espionage
item.comment: Only one play -- seems like very obvious play, but I suspect I'm missing something strategic or tactical.

item.name: 1960: The Making of the President
item.comment: Seems to favor Kennedy, what with no Nixon debate cards. More later.

item.name: 2 de Mayo
item.comment: Based on one play. Regardless that I think the Spanish player made a major strategic error in his play, I don't get a sense of urgency or intrigue from this game. It's not easy, but I also don't find it interesting.

item.name: 24/7: The Game
item.comment: I was surprised at how much I liked this one. It's simple, but still requires quite a bit of thinking. The scoring is almost self-explanatory, but intriguing. We played with four; I suspect it's even better with only two.

item.name: 6 Billion
item.comment: Long, dull, and uninspired. There's a good idea for a game in here somewhere, but the idea didn't pan out.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: Yeah, it's a thinly-themed card-drafting game with fiddly scoring, but it does all those things rather well. Where this shines is in the fact that it can seat anywhere from three to seven people without losing functionality nor taking up significantly more time.

item.name: Abalone
item.comment: It's chess crossed with sumo wrestling. Sure it can get a little bogged down in a defensive game, but it's incredibly intuitive and accessible, but still thought-provoking. Great abstract.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: It amazes me how such a simple, elegant, almost self-explanatory game can be so deep and engrossing. Compare this to, say, Rheinlander (to which it is almost identical): I can teach Acquire in five minutes, whereas Rheinlander can take fifteen minutes or more. And Acquire just feels more satisfying. This game ranks third overall in my book after Diplomacy and Scrabble.

item.name: Aeroplanes: Aviation Ascendant
item.comment: Shame on Mayfair Games for the horribly written rules that come with this game. There's no way of knowing whether we played this right based on the rules booklet that came in this game.

item.name: Age of Conan: The Strategy Board Game
Agricola
item.comment: A little bit too noninteractive for my taste, maybe the more interactive card decks fix this. Still, an interesting and engaging clockwork game with apparently quite high replay value.

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
item.comment: Agricola too long for you, or do you want it scaled properly for two players? This is the game. It's distilled Agricola; it has all the mechanisms at the root of Agricola concentrated into 45 minutes without being overpowering.

item.name: Airlines Europe
item.comment: This is a perfectly fine game, and it addresses some of the faults of Union Pacific, but it's still not as good as Union Pacific. I like the new rules for gaining the master company stock, and may house-rule them into Union Pacific. I dislike the various catch-up mechanisms injected into the game (handicapping small companies at the onset, the destination tickets for the four smallest companies), I dislike the varying costs to expand (it costs MORE to be the second company on a line?), I dislike the increasing payouts for companies, and I dislike third (and fourth and fifth) place payouts because they remove a lot of the tension and need to kee count of stocks. A worthy effort, and still a very good game, but not a great one.

item.name: Aladdin's Dragons
item.comment: The spell cards are way too powerful. Ys is better, in that at least you know what spell powers are in people's hands.

item.name: Alchemist
item.comment: Usually a designer tells you in advance what the formulas are for turning one thing into another thing and then those things into victory points. In Alchemist, the players establish those relationships, which makes for a mind-boggling, brain-burning experience. I can't even begin to describe the wheels that turn within wheels in this game, but it's clever and I kind of like it.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: Alhambra is a mess with five people, but it's really very good with three. It's even better playing with the Vezir variant, which gives players more meaningful decisions concerning collecting particular sets of buildings or constructing favorable walls.

item.name: American Megafauna
item.comment: Cool experience, but not exactly a good game.

item.name: Das Amulett
item.comment: First play shows that this game has a lot of potential, but three players is definitely not ideal. Five is probably best.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment: I really wish all the things one can do in this game had some relationship to each other.

item.name: Angkor
item.comment: Appears to be best with three players, but even then isn't all that exciting.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for British Rails

item.name: Animal Upon Animal
item.comment: If you end up playing games with kids, this is a really good place to start. Even if you're not playing with kids, I'm willing to bet that there's no group of adults that can resist the charismatic animals in this game, and slight rules tweaks make it still challenging.

item.name: Antics!
item.comment: One play -- the anthill mechanism is brilliant! The soldier ants feel a little underpowered, but we only played with three and we may have missed their utility. Maybe we're just too pacifistic to get into the arms race trope?

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: "Elegant"/"Killer whale"... They're sleek and in classic black and white.

item.name: Aqu√§dukt
item.comment: With few intereting decisions to make and a whole mess of randomness, Aquadukt fails to be a good game, at least for adults. It does look nice, and the luck can be managed, but the game is mostly a rote exercise in doing the obvious.

item.name: Architekton
item.comment: Rather dry game that isn't very compelling. I get engrossed in Fjords, whereas this game I almost play absent-mindedly. Come to think of it, I'd only want to play this game while eating.
item.conditiontext: Played several times, but in excellent condition

item.name: Ark
item.comment: It's an intereting idea and SHOULD be intuitive, but all the little rules and classifications of cards get confusing. I expect it to feel more natural -- and therefore better -- with more plays.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment: A bit too fiddly -- I'm sure I've not yet played this properly. But it's still fun with a group that's into the theme and willing to work together. It also scales extremely well, which means I carry it to more gaming days than most other games. Still, it can bog down when you have to look up again some obscure rule in the opaque rulebook.

item.name: Around the World in 80 Days
item.comment: Too random for my tastes, but certainly nothing particularly wrong with it

item.name: Atlanteon
item.comment: Nifty number-cruncher

item.name: Atlantic Star
item.comment: The ticket-drawing mechanism isn't all that inspiring, but the profits chart -- and the ablity to take out loans against your established routes -- is where this game really shines. It makes for tough decisions and interesting player interaction.

item.name: Aton
item.comment: I don't get it. I don't feel that it's possible to plan in this game, but the randomness doesn't build tension either. It seems arbitrary who wins. I don't think thought is rewarded, but it feels like it should be. Mostly uninspiring.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Clans

item.name: Atta Ants
item.comment: The five rating is for a two-player game. I think three is probably the best for this game -- hope to find out soon.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: A two-player game feels very different from a three-player, but both ways, this game is quite good. Dry, but good.

item.name: Ausgerechnet Uppsala
item.comment: Czech version (!)

item.name: Australia
item.comment: This one was not impressive at all. It felt pointless and mundane.

item.name: The Awful Green Things From Outer Space
Axiom
item.comment: While not my favorite abstract, Axiom is my favorite HARD abstract. It's an excellent game, but not something I'd pull out with just anyone. Still, this scratches the itch when my brain is screaming "HURT ME, HURT ME!"

item.name: Axis & Allies
item.comment: It's a classic, and may be showing its age a bit, but it's still a go-to for the rare occasions I can get a few people together for a full day of gaming, and everyone always has a good time.

item.name: Babel
item.comment: This game is very tactical: each turn is a puzzle that you try to best solve. Fortunately, it's a rather quick game, which makes it all worth it. And there's just enough player interaction to keep it from being simply a race.

item.name: Baccarat
item.comment: Proof that back in the day, being a European aristocrat was not in any way tied to intelligence. This game is all about muscling people into submission with large amounts of money, and has little to do with thinking. The only meaningful decision you'll make in this game is when you find yourself with a five-count.

item.name: Backgammon
item.comment: a little too luck-based for my taste -- and I'm a fairly good player. But it's a solid game, and it's not hard to find opponents.

item.name: Bananagrams
item.comment: Not up for breaking your brain over a game of Scrabble? This game is like lightning Scrabble. The interesting part is the maintenance of momentum -- the person calling for draws can keep the game in control if he knows his two-letter words or has enough places to attach hooks... but if he loses flexibility, the other player, whith a host of letters, will have an easier time making long words and can steal the momentum. This is more fluid a situation than it seems at first.

item.name: BAS-KET
item.comment: Horrible memories from my childhood -- the game surface was flimsy and quickly developed divots into which the ball would settle.

item.name: Batt'l Kha'os
item.comment: There is nothing this game does that Carcassonne doesn't do better.
item.conditiontext: Purchased at the WBC flea market; has stickers indicating it used to belong to the WBC library.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: I prefer Schotten Totten. The tactics cards are too much randomness for my taste.

item.name: BattleLore
item.comment: The lore is cool so far, but doesn't raise the game all that much higher in my esteem.

item.name: Bausack
item.comment: Mine is a Bandu set

item.name: Belfort
item.comment: Better-than-average area control cube pusher with an interesting unlock mechanism that increases the functionality of your own buildings.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment: It's a decent Halloween-themed game. Good to play with role-players.

item.name: Big Manitou
item.conditiontext: Very good condition, played only a few times

item.name: Black Box +
item.comment: The hexagon grid is a bit mind-bendy, in a good way. However, the only way to make this really a game, though, is to play face to face, taking turns being the master, and comparing how long it takes to solve each other's grids. Otherwise, it's just a puzzle.

item.name: Blitz
item.comment: Surprisingly not-trivial simple card game

item.name: Blokus
item.comment: I wish this would scale better to fewer than four players, because it's an excellent game. Totally intuitive, visually stunning, and easy for a new player to grasp without being dumbed-down.

item.name: Blokus 3D
item.comment: Similar to Blokus, but in three dimensions.

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: I'm beginning to suspect that whoever goes first wins.
item.conditiontext: Very good condition

item.name: Blokus Trigon
item.comment: Surprisingly different from the original -- it feels more tactical, and perhaps not quite as good, but it scales very well to three

item.name: Blood Bowl (Second Edition)
item.comment: Great fun back in high school. I'm partial to skaven -- they can do anything!

item.name: Blood Bowl: Team Manager ‚Äì The Card Game
Boggle
item.comment: Boggle's a great little game. Get three or four people together of roughly equal skill level and you've got a knock-down cut-throat night ahead of you.

item.name: Boggle
item.comment: This is the Turkish version -- the way Turkish works, with vowel harmony, consonant restrictions, and nearly-uniform vowel-consonant alteration, makes it a language ill-suited to Boggle.

item.name: Bolide
item.comment: Long for what it is, the vector system is really quite cool

item.name: Boss Monster: The Dungeon Building Card Game
The Bottle Imp
item.comment: Cool mechanism -- the trump cards are all the cards lower than the most recent trick-winning trump card. The last person to win with a trump card, however, has made an infernal deal and gets a handful of negative points, whereas everyone else gets the positive points they won in tricks. Wicked wicked cool.

item.name: Boxcars
item.comment: Somehow, there are people who like this game and yet think Monopoly is rubbish. I can't make sense of that.

item.name: The Bridges of Shangri-La
item.comment: There's more to this game than I'm perceiving at the moment. The first half has so many options that moves don't feel meaningful. The second half feels so constrained that there doesn't seem to be much choice in the matter. I think I'm missing something in the middle. More later.

item.name: Bumper Car Arena
item.comment: I like this game a lot, but I find it runs a bit long. Maybe reduce the score threshold to end the game and it'd be great.

item.name: Burger Joint
item.comment: Perfectly serviceable, but uninspiring two player cube-pusher. This doesn't feel like a complete game, really, but rather the economic engine for some other, better game, which was, alas, never designed.

item.name: Burgoo
item.comment: Homemade copy -- only suitable for two or three players

item.name: BuyWord
item.comment: I just don't like the bidding mechanism added to a word game; it feels like some sort of Frankenstien hodge-podge

item.name: Campaign Manager 2008
item.comment: The card-drafting system in this game is very clever, but it can make for a blowout if one person's deck is strictly inferior to the other's, which can be discouraging. But it's short enough and simulative enough that it shouldn't be alienating.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment: Two copies -- one home-made on corkboard, the other professional 1982-style.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: I really like this game for two players. More players is ok, but detracts from the strategic element quite a bit, turning it from a planning game to a what-can-I-do-with-this game.

item.name: Cards Against Humanity
item.comment: The hilarious horrifying cards get really old really fast.

item.name: Caribbean
item.comment: I usually don't like auction games, but this is both an auction and a bluff game, and the combnation works pretty well.

item.name: Carolus Magnus
item.comment: I want to like this one more, but there's something not quite right with it.
item.conditiontext: Several years old but in good condition and only played three or four times

item.name: Castle Panic
item.comment: Good basic game begging for the Wizard Tower expansion.

item.name: Castle Risk
item.comment: More misguided messing with a classic

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: Too many unintuitive options up front, and the last few turns feel needless. But an interesting idea that makes for some interesting options.

item.name: Cathedral
item.comment: I used to love this game -- it was at one time my favorite abstract. It's gotten a bit repetitive over the years, to the point that I wish I could make a few new buildings. I'll still play it, but I'd much rather play, say, Pueblo or Zertz.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: A bit too long and fiddly to get a ten, but it's still an excellent game I'd jump at the chance to play.

item.name: Chase
item.comment: Homemade copy

item.name: Chekov
item.comment: Simple but effective quick dice game

item.name: Chess
item.comment: I am rather bad at chess -- too many options, and I get lost. I'm much better, actually, at pulling a stalemate at the end after a dreadful drubbing in the early game. In any event, there's much good in chess; I just don't enjoy it all that much.

item.name: China Moon
item.comment: Not bad, but oddly blah, perhaps because we only played with three. Five seems like it would be way too chaotic, but four may be right. The downright ugly board and nearly ludicrous excuse for a story don't get in the way of the game, but the highly tactical nature of the game does make it feel longer than it is or should be.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment: I love negotiation games, and this game is nothing but. Everything is negotiable! You get semi-random assets and then wheel and deal them to try to maximize their value, and everyone is talkign all at once, all the while eyeballing other deals to see if they can jump in on them.

item.name: Chopstick Dexterity MegaChallenge 3000
item.comment: Not nearly as much fun as I was expecting, but certainly a passable bit of mindless chaos.

item.name: Chrononauts
item.comment: Surprisingly not bad card game. Even when the mechanism gets a bit dry and random, the ripple effects of actions and the weird alternate histories that build keep the game fun.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Best with two. Too chaotic with four or more.

item.name: La Citt√†
item.comment: It's an unforgiving slog-fest, but is nonetheless deep in both strategy and tactics.

item.name: Civilization
item.comment: Too much clunkiness for this to be enjoyable. Lots of down-time, interminable trading sessions, high degree of high-impact randomness in the calamities, and an unintuitive population-tax trade-off. Even when I do well in this game it's painful.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment: A style of game I especially like is divide-the-spoils, where a player has to organize things that other people get to choose from. This game is a slowed down version of this; each player adds one item to a tableu of options until people finally decide that their options just won't get better.

item.name: Confusion: Espionage and Deception in the Cold War
Conquest of Planet Earth: The Space Alien Game
Cranium
item.comment: Fun party game for when you have too many people to play Apples to Apples coherently.

item.name: Creationary
item.comment: Great idea for a game, but there aren't enough pieces for the things you're supposed to build. How do you make a blackboard if there aren't any standard black pieces? You'll need to buy some supplemental Legos, but it may actually be worth it.

item.name: The Creature That Ate Sheboygan
item.comment: Great fun eating Wisconsin. I know I'm overrating this game, but theme counts for a lot here.

item.name: Creeper
item.comment: Rather good game, but annoying pieces.

item.name: Cribbage
item.comment: Traditional British games have such fiddly rules, and this is no exception. But this one works. I survived a summer in France playing this game with a classmate.

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: Somewhat better as a four-player game than as a two-player, but really good either way.

item.name: Cronberg
item.conditiontext: Played a few times, but complete and in excellent condition. My copy is Cronberg, not Bonobo Beach.

item.name: Cuba
item.comment: Possibly, the most beautiful-looking game I own. The game play is also really interesting; you start with plantations generating basic resources, but you build your immprovements on top of those plantations, limiting your resource income. Add in voting on rule-changes and an econmoic market sequence, and you've got a fairly complex but accessible game.

item.name: Darjeeling
item.comment: Rather interesting game with a lot more interaction than it would seem at first, in that you have to keep small shipments in hand to keep a person from perpetually earning huge points off a large shipment. The scoring seems to move a little bit too fast, which makes the game end sooner than I'd like.

item.name: Days of Steam
item.comment: Carcassonne meets Age of Steam. Sort of. It seems hard to get anything going in this game, but that's only after one play. More to come, I'm sure.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment: Really really fiddly rules, but has lots of potential

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
Desperados
item.comment: I'm not convinced I made any meaningful decisions in this game, but it's mostly harmless.

item.name: Diaballik
item.comment: My copy is homemade

item.name: Diabolo
item.comment: Interesting, but it seems too easy to get stuck with bad cards after their suits get locked, which makes for annoying pain

item.name: Diam
item.comment: Clever abstract; nothing spectacular, but solid and fairly quick. I have been finding it especially difficult to see losing situations coming in this one so it will probably maintain my interest.

item.name: Diplomacy
item.comment: My high school swim team played this nearly every other week for two years straight. I have incredibly fond memories of it and, perhaps uncharacteristically of the game, we never had any fights over it. I miss those days when you could get seven people together for a whole day of gaming.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: Good mechanism stunted by repetitive play with interminable shuffling. I expect that there will be a handful of fairly- to very-good games that adopt this card-drafting feature. Thunderstone, perhaps?

item.name: Dos Rios
item.comment: Sort of anticlimactic. The river redirection mechanism is really very cool, but the rest of the game is jsut dull. Part of the reason is that the win conditions -- just build buildings -- are less than stellar.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Metropolys

item.name: Drako
item.comment: Quick, easy asymmetric tactical combat game -- the dragon theme melds really well with the mechanisms.

item.name: Dreidel
item.comment: It's not a game, it's gambling. And it's not even good gambling.

item.name: Druid
item.comment: Interesting connection game, vaguely reminiscent of Twixt, though obviously not the same at all. The building upward part makes it unique and worth playing.

item.name: DruidenWalzer
item.comment: I have no idea what's going on in this game, but I know I like it. There's wheels turning within wheels and everything is always moving, and it all just barely makes sense. Good brain-bender.

item.name: Dune
item.comment: I so wanted to like this game, but it's such a garbled hodge-podge of stuff. We had constant disputes over interpreting the rules (and had to muddle through the original French for adjudication) and incessant queries of "what happens now?" or "what does this do?" I'd far far prefer just playing Diplomacy.

item.name: Dungeoneer: Dragons of the Forsaken Desert
Dungeoneer: Tomb of the Lich Lord
Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: Conquest of Nerath Board Game
item.comment: Fine enough game. I just see no reason to play this when I can just play Axis & Allies.

item.name: DVONN
item.comment: The GIPF games get their charm from the fact that each game has two gimmicks that work together to create interesting emergent dynamics. In this game, you have on the one hand pieces that move further and further as the board shrinks in size, and on the other the pepperonis of power, contiguety with which keeps peices in the game. Controlling access to the pepperonis makes for interesting tactical and strategic decisions unavailable in similar board-shrinking games.

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment: Not bad; tricky even. Feels a bit forced and constrained, but all in all a good experience.

item.name: Elchfest
item.comment: This game is just great stupid fun. Good stuff.

item.name: Elder Sign
item.comment: It's a lot of theme with no plot, which is fine, but not an exceptional experience.

item.name: Elfenland
item.comment: I don't mind games that don't give you many options -- in the right circumstances, those games can be fun. I cannot, however, tolerate a game that systematically nullifies all of your planning, all of your strategy, arbitrarily. This is the only game I can think of that I would absoltely refuse to play again.

item.name: Empire Builder
item.comment: It's darn cool to be able to draw on the board. the game can be a bit slow in the middle when people are mostly just racing around picking stuff up and dropping it off.

item.name: Empires of the Void
item.comment: Too much detail superimposed over not enough actual game. For all the detail spent on technology tree and combat ships and variety of planets and all, there aren't enough events, not enough feel of territory building, and (to me) a way unbalanced disparity in how you get victory points.

item.name: Entdecker
item.comment: A good idea that just didn't work

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
Euchre
item.comment: Nothing special; nothing bad

item.name: Europa 1945-2030
item.comment: Who'd have thought that a game about love and peace and togetherness could be so cutthroat? This is another one my Philly friends love. It's a good solid negotiation game for when you can't get enough people together for enough time to play Diplomacy... which is most of the time.

item.name: Eurorails
item.comment: The main reason to play this or any other game in this series is because you get to draw on the board. Otherwise, it's a pretty straightforward economic race game. Which isn't bad, it's just not as interesting as some of the other options out there, like, say, Age of Steam, which is much more tense.

item.name: Executive Decision
item.comment: This isn't a game. It's work, and work I don't get paid for. This game put me off gaming for a day or two.

item.name: Factory Fun
item.comment: A bit of a brain-burner, but really cool. I wish it were easier to keep track of what one sepnds every turn.

item.name: Facts in Five
item.comment: I personally prefer to make up our own categories than use the cards - doing so puts the difficulty of the game somewhere between standard Facts on Five and Scattergories, which seems to be around the right level of fun.

item.name: Fastrack
item.comment: Quick stupid fast-paced dexterity fun

item.name: Fearsome Floors
item.comment: With two players this game is dullish. With four it was wickedly fun.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment: I don't usually like blind bidding, but this one seems to work really well, at least for three players. The tension of the gradually revealed hand and the desire to pass as late as possible really work well together.

item.name: Fjords
item.comment: It's Carcassonne light for two people (which in of itself isn't all that inspiring) but it's good. If you don't have time to figure out the farmers at the end of a Carcassonne game, this one is probably a better bet. It's also more portable.

item.name: Flandern 1302
item.conditiontext: Good condition, played three or four times

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment: The theme in this game is so incredibly strong, even moreso than Pandemc, to which it is superficially similar. The various maps offer different challenges, and the random spread of hazards combined with inherent dangers on the board are what build the constant tension that makes the game interesting. The various character powers are distinct and all are interesting. But the real innovation here is the ability of a player to swap out the character he's playing when the situation shifts to favor other special powers... but it takes precious time.

item.name: Flowerpower
item.comment: For all the love this game gets, I'm mildly disappointed. The incremental scoring is interesting, and makes for some unintuitive play, but I don't see how this shines in comparison to some of the other Kosmos 2-player games.

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment: Snorefest

item.name: Formidable Foes
item.comment: A war crime in a box. It's been quite a while since I've had less fun playing a game (it would have been Executive Decision). This is clunky, fiddly, downright unwieldy, and too clever for its own good. It's entirely possible that you end up in a situation in which no one can win at all, which could be cool for a game about nuclear war, but shouldn't be the case for something as light-hearted as this. I give it points for having a decent narrative and really good art, but really, play Dungeon instead.

item.name: Formula D√©
item.comment: A decent game -- the roll-and-move aspect is uninspiring, but the gear-shift changes and the risk management of wearing down tires and brakes makes it interesting. With the wrong crowd, it can be a disaster, though, as people wander off if they think they're too far behind.

item.name: Fragile
item.comment: Spacial puzzle game -- finding the ways to get other players' dockworkers to work for you is the most interesting part.

item.name: Friday the 13th
item.comment: Nifty card game -- nothing spectacular about it, but good for a light, if thought-provoking, interlude.

item.name: Funny Friends
item.comment: The anorexia card rocks.

item.name: Fury of Dracula (second edition)
item.comment: A souped-up Scotland Yard. The theme allows for a lot of really good added detail in the cards and combat. Also rather well-balanced both in terms of the luck/strategy balance and the hunters/Dracula balance.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: Cross Factory Fun with The Great Space Race and you get Galaxy Trucker. It's a time pressure puzzle coupled with a brutal game of attrition, and the ensuing tragedy still manages to be fun, a la Roborally. Really surprisingly good stuff.

item.name: The Game of Life
item.comment: snore...

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
Gene Pool
item.comment: A bit humdrum -- nothing Phoenix doesn't do a bit better.

item.name: The Generals
item.comment: Interesting attempt to make Stratego a full secret information game, but it eventually fails. The gimmick -- the computer telling you who wins -- is good, but the rank structure is too detailed. They should just have kept the Stratego army structure, and this would have been quite the gem.

item.name: Genoa
item.comment: I don't remember it well enough to comment, but I remember having a very strong negative reaction.

item.name: Gheos
item.comment: The tile replacement rules makes the game far too fluid, but it's nonetheless clever.

item.name: Ghosts!
item.comment: This and Xe Queo are the two essential doublethink bluff games.

item.name: Gipsy King
item.comment: Scoring seems a bit imbalanced, but it's certainly not a bad game at all.

item.name: Glen More
item.comment: This is a good, relatively light clockwork game, where you build little economic machine; trick is these machines eventually run down as the opportunities to activate them run out, forcing you to keep building new ones.

item.name: Go
item.comment: I know this is a good game. I just don't find it fun or interesting.

item.name: Go to the Head of the Class
Granada: The Fall of Moslem Spain
item.comment: The option to put troops in reserve to interrupt your opponent's move is rather clever.

item.name: Grave Robbers From Outer Space
item.comment: Cannibal Dracula's Maniac Fungus Lust, Part IV

item.name: The Great Space Race
item.comment: The most interesting turn of the one time I played this was when my ship blew up. This game tries to be too much -- the chaos of RoboRally with the length of Formula De and the fidgetiness of Betrayal at House on the Hill or Civilization -- and gets lost in itself. Maybe it would be better if you only run two laps.

item.name: Greed
item.comment: This game ain't half bad

item.name: Groo: The Game
item.comment: Not a game for two

item.name: Gyges
item.comment: My copy is home-made on corkboard

item.name: Hanabi & Ikebana
item.comment: The rating is for Hanabi, which is a really innovative cooperative card game. You have to collectively rely on little bits of information you tell each other to deduce what cards to play.

item.name: Hansa
item.comment: This is what I call a clockwork game. There are a handful of rules that interact like machinery and each move is sort of like a mini puzzle you try to most effectively sovle. Low on player interaction, but pretty solid.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment: This is a really impressive design, but I think there's far too much going on for it to actually be fun. I can't think of any circumstances where I'd rather play this over Agricola.

item.name: Hellas
item.comment: Hellas seems far too fluid to be a coherent wargame.

item.name: Hermagor
item.comment: Hermagor is a kludge of all the nifty mechanics that made other games (Power Grid, Thurn and Taxis, Ys, Himalaya) great. The various mechanics barely hold together as Hermagor clumsily lumbers about, staggering under its own weight and top-heaviness. It's not a bad game, but it's incredibly inelegant. Sadly, the board, though beautiful, is confusing and impractical, being more a detraction from play than a suppliment to it.

item.name: Hexagony
item.comment: The game feels interesting, but not fun. Part of the problem is that the combat system seems to reward defensiveness, which means the game could degenerate into everyone just shifting pieces around or endlessly collecting resources. A two player game of this might be very rewarding, though.

item.name: Hey, That's My Fish!
item.comment: Simple rules, medium-depth strategy, high on tactics, this is an evil evil game, hidden behind the guise of cartoon penguins.

item.name: The High Kings of Tara
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Croa

item.name: High Tail It!
item.comment: Simple rules, quick but moderately deep play, cute theme... whats not to like?

item.name: Hive
item.comment: This is probably my fourth-favorite abstract of the moment (after Quorridor, Axiom, and Zhadu). Quick and easy to comprehend, but still deep in both strategy and tactics. Great to take to a restaurant and play while the food is being prepared. And the pieces are nice and sturdy.

item.name: Hoity Toity
item.comment: It's rock paper scissors crossed with rummy. Which is to say it has a point arbitrarily arrived at. No thank you.

item.name: Horus
item.comment: Finally, an Egypt game I like!

item.name: Imperial
item.comment: I like it, but it has flaws (Britain too weak, Italy too strong, for instance).
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Caylus

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment: A solid game of attrition management -- you're going to lose something, so how best can you manipulate it so that you lose things when they are least valuable?

item.name: Inevitable
item.comment: Funny content, Monopoly-like gameplay, but without the property trading.

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment: I used to really like this one, but it got to be very repetitive. Now, I can take it or leave it.

item.name: Inkognito: The Card Game
item.comment: Very basic deduction game, but with a partnership element, which is interesting. I suspect this might be a better game with six players, actually, as there would be much more uncertainty over who one's partner is. Even still, I don't find this one particularly inspiring.
item.conditiontext: Played once, and thus missing four info sheets.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment: The cards are way too complex for what should otherwise be a quick and breezy game.

item.name: Irondale
item.comment: I'm not convinced we played his right. But the text-heavy cards, combined with a quirky discard and draw mechanism and a mechanism by which many of the cards on the table have lingering effects makes for very very very slow play.

item.name: Ithaka
item.comment: Homemade copy

item.name: Jaipur
item.comment: Quick and nifty little card-trading game. It doesn't seem like anything special, but I always have a minor blast playing it. The pressure to trade early and the pressure to trade big greate enough tension to really balance the game.

item.name: James Ernest's Totally Renamed Spy Game
Java
item.comment: My brain, my brain! This grinds to a halt three-fourths of the way through. I suspect it's better with two than with more.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Thud

item.name: Jotto
item.comment: I remember this from when I was little -- Mastermind and Boggle sort of rolled into one

item.name: The Journeys of Paul
item.comment: Standard race game, with low player interaction. Not bad, really, but there are other race games I'd rather play.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Grenada

item.name: Jumpin
item.comment: Oddly uninspiring, particularly at the end when both players are shuffling their pieces around trying to fit them in. The pieces are really cool, though.
item.conditiontext: Good condition

item.name: Kamon
item.comment: Interesting connection/forced action abstract with a little bit of Set in the mix. I suspect this rating will rise. Oh, and the game smells like a brand new car.

item.name: Kensington
item.comment: Slow, dragged out abstract with a vicious circle mechanism by which losing one piece dooms you to losing all the rest little by little. Chess can be that way, too, but with chess, fewer pieces can open the board and give more movement options and surprise attacks. Not so here.

item.name: Khan Tsin
item.comment: How does this work as a game? I don't know, but it does, and the endgame can be quite the brainburner.

item.name: Khet: The Laser Game
item.comment: Lasers are cool and all, but the game is a bit slow to develop.

item.name: Kingdoms
item.comment: Gets very repetitive very fast.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment: Best played with three people, I think, in that the board is crowded enough that decisions are tough, but not so crowded that everyone has leftover dice. Also, the game runs awfully long with more than three. It's an interesting game utilizing dice well, and caputring the city-building and defending theme well.

item.name: Koi Pond: A Coy Card Game
Krak√≥w 1325 AD
item.comment: This felt slower and more cumbersome than Revolution. Perhaps with more plays and more familiarity withthe cards, it will be better. It's not really bad, it just takes a lot more time to accomplish what other games do just as well more quickly.

item.name: Kremlin
item.comment: Politics pure and simple. Get your guy to the top and keep him there despite the machinations of your opponents to do the same. The rules are a bit convoluted, but there's a natural flow to the game that starts to become second-nature. And then there's the glee of rooting for someone else's doddering old apparatchik to kick it when the mortality die comes around.

item.name: Kreta
item.comment: This kind of feels like El Grande lite. It plays fairly quickly and has an interesting combination of some good familiar mechanics.

item.name: Kulami
item.comment: Simple rules, quick play, easy set-up, but doesn't feel trivial at all. I'm not convinced the first half of the game is much more than random, but the end game makes for interesting decisions. THree different ways to score shoudl also keep it interesting after repeated play.

item.name: Kupferkessel Co.
item.comment: The recipe cards make the game more focused and confrontational, but not necessarily better. Good tactical game, though, with an interesting memory element.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
Leaping Lemmings
item.comment: Only GMT could produce a game about minute rodents and STILL have it involve stacking limits.

item.name: Legendary Encounters: A Predator Deck Building Game
Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
Leonardo da Vinci
item.comment: Mind-bogglingly bad. The rules are incredibly badly-written, inspiring a number of animated discussions about what the proper interpretation of them should be. Then there's the overused impress someone in Italy during the Renaisance theme. Then there's the ugly, confusing, badly-designed board. Ditto the cards. On top of that, the game itself is almost entirely a hodge-podge of the nifty little tactical elements from games like Puerto Rico, Caylus, and Outpost, but all those bits don't fit together well at all. The result is a highly tactical, highly luck-driven game that quickly swamps the (randomly determined) trailers in a vicious cycle of failure. I want my three hours of life back.

item.name: Liar's Dice
item.comment: I play by Perudo rules

item.name: Liebrary
item.comment: While not exactly a good game, it is a fun game, and tickles the creative side in me.

item.name: The Little Prince: Make Me a Planet
Looting London
item.comment: Removing the money and auctions from Modern Art was decidedly a good thing. But it's still not a particularly exciting or even interesting game.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
item.comment: Too many special rules for too short a game. I'd rather play Stratego.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Duel
Lords of Vegas
item.comment: So, in your group, there's one person who likes the negotiation in Chinatown, and another person who likes the business growth of Acquire, and a third person who likes the push your luck elements of something like Can't Stop. This is the game for you. It isn't exactly better than any of these other games, but it does mix the various elements of those games together very well and it carries a theme that makes all the mechanisms make sense together.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: This is incredibly dry, and even though the scoring is basic math, it makes my head spin. I will only agree to play this because it's short.

item.name: M
item.comment: Very dry and unengaging, but certainly playable as a two-player game.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Terrace

item.name: Die Macher
item.comment: I've only played it once, but I absolutely love it and would jump at another chance to go at it. Unfortunately it's way long... Someday...

item.name: Machine of Death: The Game of Creative Assassination
item.comment: There's some interesting story-telling in this game, but I'm not convinced the actual game mechaniss work right.

item.name: Magic: The Gathering
item.comment: The simpler the cards, the better the game. Magic got so carried away and complex that it started to debase its own system, which is a shame. But it's still fun.

item.name: Die Magier von Pangea
item.comment:
Oh, this one should be so good, but it's not. It degenerates into fast-paced tactical place-management until someone misses something their neighbor can do to win. Too bad -- great idea.
On second thought, this may be rather a good game fro two people -- looking into that possibility.

item.name: Magna Grecia
item.conditiontext: A few years old, but only played once. Good condition.

item.name: Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
Malawi
item.comment: Potentially interesting hybrid of mancala and chess. I need to play it more to know for sure how good it is.

item.name: Mall of Horror
item.comment: A game with four is better than with three. It's great evil fun.

item.name: Mammoth Hunters
item.comment: This game isn't bad, but there's nothing particularly good about it either.

item.name: Mao
item.comment: This is for people who like to be frustrated, but then to feel that rush of belonging that comes with catching on and suddenly feeling "in". I am not one of those people. This game just makes me angry.

item.name: March Madness
item.comment: The amount of time that one wastes during this alleged game between making actual decisions is enormous. It's not quite automatic, but in a way, I think I'd rather it be.

item.name: Mare Nostrum
item.comment: Curiously boring.

item.name: Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers vs. X-Men
Marvel Heroes
item.comment: Too fiddly, I think, but good theme. The weaknesses built into the game are actually interesting -- a lot hinges on how to best avoid them, which is, after all, quite thematic. Good stuff.

item.name: Meander
item.comment: Not bad, but not exactly exciting

item.name: Medici
item.comment: A simple game of brain-stunning depth. This game melts away all the flash leaving the meat of any game at its core -- the assessment of a move's value to yourself and to others. If it were less dry, it'd get a ten, but as it is, it's still an excellent nine.

item.name: Medici vs Strozzi
item.comment: I'm surprised at how well this game manages to capture the feel of Medici. Is it as good as Medici? I'm not sure -- it doesn't feel it, but I can't figure out why. More later.

item.name: Medina
item.comment: How can something with such simple rules and pieces be so evil and deep? It looks beautiful and, though it sounds like a dry experience, is actually really compelling and engaging. The only problem with the game is that often you feel like you're settling for the least bad option rather than picking a good option; otherwise it'd be a ten.

item.name: Memory
item.comment: This is actually pretty darn good, given that there's almost nothing to it. I have played this against intelligent adults and still have had a good time with it.

item.name: Merchant of Venus
item.comment: Dreadful dreadful game, horribly imbalanced against the last player, far far too random for a game of such a length, mostly pointless. I'd be very happy if I never play this again

item.name: Meridian
item.comment: This rating is for a two-player game -- surprisingly good, actually.

item.name: Metropolys
item.comment: Rather clever tactical game with a lot to think about. The board is incredibly garish though... distractingly so.

item.name: Midgard
item.comment: Sort of El Grande in reverse, but I really don't like it. There's way too much chaos to make sense of it all, but so many little details that people take forever thinking before taking their turn. The card drafting should be a good idea, but curiously isn't, and the map is, well, totally unnecessary.

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment: This game is an exercise in narcolepsy for me. Dreary deary dreary. I have more fun losing at Uno than I do winning at Modern Art.

item.name: Monsters Menace America
item.comment: Stupid fun, but lacking depth that would make it stand out above the run-of-the-mill dicefest.

item.name: Mord im Arosa
item.comment: While not exactly a good game, the listening mechanism and component quality of this game make it charming, fun, and completely novel.

item.name: M√ºnchhausen
item.conditiontext: Played once

item.name: My Word!
item.comment: This was a stinker. It's trying to be Snatch or Word Exchange, but sacrificed some of the elegance of those games and as a result became confusing, unintuitive, and painful.

item.name: Mykerinos
item.comment: So, I've played this one twice and I'm just not getting it. It's really boring. I'll give it another chance or so, but, honestly, I'm disappointed.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Druidenwalzer

item.name: Nanofictionary
item.comment: Kathy Fidler tells great stories; she always wins, but it's great to lose to her because of the tales she weaves.

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: There's a lot of good in this game, but the end seems to come at an arbitrary moment. In the two-player games I've had of this, the tide will often turn, but it's really hard to figure out why.

item.name: Niagara
item.comment: I think this game is prone to dragging down (and thus becoming unfun) when played by veteran gamers -- because they'll constantly be thwarting each others' possible wins. For a light social group, this is probably a winner.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Kamon

item.name: Notre Dame
item.comment: Hardly elegant, but full of tight resource allocation problems and varied paths to victory, this is a solid complex Euro. The card drafting mechanism is really nice, and the tension between building resource factories and putting out fires is interesting.

item.name: Oasis
item.comment: My Philly friends love this and call it Camelpalooza. It would be a totally unremarkable game were it not for the bidding mechanism that also involves a heavy dose of push-your-luck. There's a social element to it too -- gaming what you think other players will do -- that makes this a rather clever game. A mixed group of gamers and non-gamers can handle this one easily.

item.name: Octiles
item.comment: This should be a great elegant abstract (with a touch of luck) but the board gets too congested. I've played with less than the full set of pieces per player and that helps a bit.

item.name: Oltre Mare
item.comment: I really dislike cards with multiple purposes, and whoo boy, Oultremere has that in spades.

item.name: On the Underground
item.comment: Figuring out the traveller's path is a bit obtuse, but all in all there's a clever game here.

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
Outpost
item.comment: OK, I got crushed the one time I played this. But it was obvious who was going to win well before the game was half-over. I don't think I would have enjoyed winning under those circumstances, either.

item.name: Owner's Choice
item.comment: This looked really bad, but was surprisingly not bad -- my main complaint is actually that the game rips along so quickly that one really doesn't get a chance to let strategies mature fully. The variance in capabilities of the companies (as reflected on their owners' dice) is a real charmer.

item.name: Palatinus
item.comment: An interesting game sort of reminiscent of Ys. The effects that cascade as a result of resolving soldiers at different times in reference to the scoring of hills makes for some interesting considerations.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: Surprisingly difficult. A losing situation resolves itself quickly enough that it doesn't get tedious -- in fact, a loss is really more of an invitiation to try again.

item.name: Parthenon: Rise of the Aegean
item.comment: Three points for the fact that with the nihilist ability you can ignore bad thigns that happen -- that's cool. The rest of the game was dull and sloggish.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords ‚Äì Base Set
Patrician
item.comment: A disaster with two players, it works fine with three. There's a cool bit of cascade effect going on in this game.

item.name: Pentago
item.comment: Good, quick abstract which bends the mind a bit. Just deep enough to continue being interesting for multiple continuous plays.

item.name: Phoenicia
item.comment: Someone left the fun out of the box. There's a game here, but the parts grind together painfully, unlubricated by anything interesting or thought-provoking. Add to that unintuitive graphics and an unclear rulebook, and you have a barely playable klunker. If you call that "playing."

item.name: Phoenix
item.comment: Light and tactical, but still vicious fun.

item.name: Piece o' Cake
item.comment: Interesting take on the divide and offer mechanism. Coloretto still does it better, but this one gives the option of cutting your losses on things you don't want, which helps people who are stuck with a lot of dregs, but also introduces a bit of risk management for players who are ahead in a category: do you score your excess and risk being surpassed, or do you forego points to ensure you maintain your category leads?

item.name: Pipeline
item.comment: This game is a war crime with four people. It might be tolearable with two.

item.name: Pizza Theory
item.comment: Really interesting area majority game in which the size and shape of the areas changes from turn to turn, and the players only have partial control over those changes. There's some bluffing and mind-reading involved. Plus, with the anchovy expansion, the game can win, which makes the decisions even more interesting.

item.name: PlanQuadrat
item.comment: Really good abstract; sort of a cross between Cathedral and the box game, improving on both.

item.name: Poison Pot
item.comment: Rather a clever game. However, I'll point out that though the production quality of PIN games is generally pretty good, the design of some of their pieces is really annoying -- in this case, mixing up the pots while they're upside-down without knocking them over is pointedly difficult.

item.name: Polarity
item.comment: I have no idea how this game works.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: If the rules to this were a little less fiddly, it'd be a ten. But as it stands I always either forget something or nearly forget something. Great economic simulation though.

item.name: Power Grid: Factory Manager
item.comment: Pretty good efficiency management game, but it's no Power Grid, and it's not even as good as Industrial Waste.

item.name: Princess Ryan's Star Marines
item.comment: Surprisingly good cooperative adventure game, perhaps a precursor to Lord of the Rings. The time element makes for a rather tense game. There are some elements that are almsot certainly broken, but they are easily remedied.

item.name: Pueblo
item.comment: Every time I play this game I'm reminded just how much I really like it, so it probably warrants more than a seven. The anguish of trying to fit your piece in that almost-perfect place over and over again (just in case you missed something) is ecstatic agony.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: The trick to this game is catching a wave, such that you are prepared to benefit from other people's choices. Getting onto that wave is a tough, challenging exercise, but very rewarding.

item.name: P√úNCT
item.comment: The Gipf series sort of dried up with this one. I don't think the odd-shaped, moveable, stackable pieces have made this better than any other connection game. That said, it's not bad. It just doesn't shine the way Zertz and Yinsh do, and the mechanic isn't novel the way Tamsk's is.

item.name: Pylos
item.comment: Play verges on automatic once you get to know the game well. And automatic translates to boring. But the pieces are nice and it's a good warm-up game for a non-gamer interested in playing abstracts. Still, even under those circumstances, Quorridor is probably a better pick.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Ark

item.name: Q*bert Card Game
item.comment: Cute and mildly fun, with a heavy dose of nostalgia value for me.

item.name: Quarto!
item.comment: Pretty cool and a bit mind-melting

item.name: Queen's Necklace
item.comment: Choices seemed pretty forced, and randomness seems a bit high, but all in all, not a bad game.

item.name: Quoridor
item.comment: Quorridor is my favorite abstract -- it's intuitive, it looks great, it plays well, it has just the right amount of confrontation without verging on acrimony... great stuff. The reason I give it a ten is because it's a great gateway game. Nongamers can absorb the rules easily and identify with the goal quickly; it's fast enough that it doesn't get mired down; and people can get good at it very quickly, so after, say, three games, the players are on close-to-even footing. If I were to bring a game along on a date, this is the one I'd pick.

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment: Very pleasantly surprised by this one. It's sort of Scrabble for the illiterate, but in a good way. This would serve as a good game to introduce strategic position play and rack management to aspiring Scrabble masters.

item.name: Qyshinsu: Mystery of the Way
item.comment: At first unintuitive, it eventually starts to develop its own logic and turns out to be unique and clever. Occasionally a series of moves will turn out to be forcedly undone later.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: Ugh, I hate this auction system.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: I'm not a fan of games in which cards fill multiple roles (as developments, goods, money, and so on). On top of that, this game just felt like it ended just as tings started rolling.

item.name: Railways of the World
item.comment: Cards seem to needlessly complicate an otherwise good idea for a game.

item.name: Rat Hot
item.comment: Extremely light, but you get a good deal of payoff for what little thinking is there. Rat accumulation builds just the right amount of tension. Good game to play with conversation or a snack.

item.name: Reef Encounter
item.comment: This game feels like a well-oiled machine. Each player is turning gears to set up beneficial chain reactions. I'm impressed by the precision and interactivity of the mechanics, but that same trait makes the game a tad soulless.

item.name: Regatta
item.comment: This game feels like it's a good simulation of what it's like to sail a boat -- right of way rules, tacking, projecting a course -- just without the feeling of the wind in your hair and water below you. Which means that, really, it's very dull.

item.name: Relationship Tightrope
item.comment: The theme is awful, but the game is good

item.name: The Republic of Rome
item.comment: It's Diplomacy without the board. And without the point.

item.name: Res Publica
item.comment: It's slow-motion Pit

item.name: Revolution!
item.comment: Surprisingly good area control game. The mechanisms for keeping stragglers in the game are thematic and fresh, the play is interesting but not complicated... my only concern is replayability.

item.name: Rheinl√§nder
item.comment: At first blush, this comes off as an Acquire variant. But the new geography, more flexible expansion rules, and special powers of some of the locations allow it to stand on its own. It falls short of a ten in that you cannot reinvest money back into the gameplay as you can in Acquire.

item.name: Ricochet Robots
item.comment: I'd rather play this one alone, which makes it more of a puzzle than a game. The bidding structure is flawed and dealing with the bids in sequence makes it very hard to remember your solution.

item.name: Risk 2210 A.D.
item.comment: I don't understand why Risk gets a bad rap and this one is so widely praised. Risk is a classic in all senses off the word, whereas this feels forced, cramped, and, eventually, just silly.

item.name: River Dragons
item.comment: Best with two or three. Way too much chaos with more.

item.name: Roads & Boats
item.comment: The game doesn't last long enough -- there's all sorts of fun buildings to build, but by the time you can build them, the game's over. Shame.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
RoboRally
item.comment: Gotta love that Twonky.

item.name: Robotory
item.comment: Clever little tug of war game, which feels a bit too short for what it is.

item.name: Rosenk√∂nig
item.comment: Good simple two-player that makes for some tough tactical decision-making.

item.name: Rrib-Bit
item.comment: My board is home-made, 9x9

item.name: Rummikub
item.comment: yawn

item.name: Russian Rails
item.comment: Better than the other rails games I've played -- the open contracts and the fall of the wall add a bit of complexity the others lack.

item.name: Sahara
item.comment: Fair but not exceptional abstract involving pyramids tumbling all over. Not bad, but there are many better games that will fill the same niche.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment: I dislike games that use cards for everything; I find them confusing and curiously boring. San Juan is a perfect example of how this genre can go utterly bad, taking something sublime (Puerto Rico) and making it just sub.

item.name: San Marco
item.comment: The card division and offering really makes this game an exercise in psychology and tough decisions.

item.name: Santorini
item.comment: Rather nifty abstract. The tension comes in getting your two pieces to cooperate as best as possible while trying to box your opponent into an unworkable situation. Darn cool.

item.name: Scarab Lords
item.comment: This game is curiously uncompelling. Who's going to win? Who cares? Part of the problem, I think, is that the decks aren't clearly good vs. evil or merchants vs. warlords or anyone vs. anyone else. Who are these factions? What does it mean if one wins? Is the other enslaved? Exterminated? Incredibly embarrassed? Dull, dull, dull.
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus.

item.name: Scattergories
item.comment: It's quite fun to see what people come up with for answers. There's always that one answer you think is unbeatable that someone else also writes down. Like elasmosaurus.

item.name: The Scepter of Zavandor
item.comment: Scepter of Zavandor is the oral surgery of gaming. The beginning is pelasant and diverting, sort of like when the anesthetic sets in, but then about halfway through it becomes a prolonged agony. It's better than Outpost in the way that Stalin was better than Hitler: somewhat more interesting and complex, but just as painful.

item.name: Schotten-Totten
item.comment: Tense card game involving building mini poker hands.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: Scrabble gets a bad rap, which is sad and unfair. The first of two main reasons people don't like it is because they think it's a family game. There's a lot of strategy to Scrabble -- in terms of placing tiles so that they only benefit you -- that gets lost if you aren't serious enough about the game. The other main complaint is that it is somehow "unfair" if someone knows (or has memorized) more words than someone else. How this is any different from memorizing chess openings or go patterns is beyond me. Many people don't take Scrabble as seriously as they should because it's "just" a word game, and that's really a shame, 'cause those people are missing out.

item.name: Sekigahara: The Unification of Japan
item.comment:
Full disclosure: I was a playtester for this game, and am a good friend of the desgner.
I have always liked the concept of fog of war block games, but have found them to be oddly lacking (with the exceptions of Napoleon and WestFront). This game spices up the block game genre by adding an added level of fog. Sure, your opponent doesn't know what troops you have, but likewise you yourself have only limited control over which of the troops you have will be willing to fight for you on any given turn. This adds a very difficult and, to me, satisfying element of hand management to the game. Filtering your hand so that you can motivate mixed armies in the short term while simultaneously engineering your hand to match the forces available in your primary army in anticipation for an epic smackdown is really very tough, but also very satisfying.
item.conditiontext: Second unopened copy still in shrink.

item.name: Sentinel Tactics: The Flame of Freedom
Sharp Shooters
item.comment: Ok for what it is. Can't Stop is a far better game in the same vein.

item.name: Shazamm!
item.comment: Nifty little wizard duel game

item.name: Shear Panic
item.comment: High on tactics and whimsy, Shear Panic is quite fun. A four player game has quite a lot of chaos, whereas two may not have quite enough. I've not played with three, but I suspect that three is not just good but best for this game. That said, the lack of much ability for strategic planning takes it down a point or two.

item.name: Ship, Captain, and Crew
item.comment: Mind-numbing gambling game in which you have a meaningful choice perhaps once in twenty games.

item.name: Siam
item.comment: First thing first, the pieces in this game are really beautiful. I was worried that the gameplay wouldn't live up to the pieces, and though that may be true, the game itself is also still quite good. The rules aren't well explained though, and there's a bit of fiddliness on win conditions, but all in all, a good game experience.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
Silk Road
item.comment: Way too long for what it is, but the system gaming is intriguing.

item.name: Sim Serim
item.comment: My copy is home-made on corkboard

item.name: Skybridge
item.comment: Interesting abstract, but hardly elegant with some oddly fiddly placement rules. Still, it requires a bit of thought and a lot opportunity analysis.

item.name: Sleuth
item.comment: This game hurts your brain, but in a good way. And I think I've finally perfected my information tracking system...

item.name: Snake Pit
item.comment: Perfectly serviceable and harder than it looks, but not exactly exciting.

item.name: Snatch
item.comment: Very simple Scrabble-trainer; letters come up and you make words ouot of them, hopefully anagramming your opponents' words into them to make something bigger and harder to steal.

item.name: Sorry!
item.comment: As written, Sorry is pretty lame. You can make it much better by allowing each player a hand of three cards. Draw a card, play a card.

item.name: Space Dealer
item.comment: This was the best game I'd played in ages for about ten minutes. Then the novelty wore off and I realized it's a mediocre game with a mildly interesting but ultimately annoying mechanic. Especially annoying was the feeling that building anything benefitted my opponents far more than it did me.

item.name: Space Hop
item.comment: This one has been bothering me for YEARS, and I finally remembered the name! We got this at the Adler Planetarium in Chicago when I was really young and I remember playing it a LOT, particularly on the floor in my grandparents' living room. It's a crappy game now, I'm sure, but it was darn cool at the time.

item.name: Speed Circuit
item.comment: Surprisingly dull, but not exactly bad, either

item.name: Spinnentwist
item.comment: This one rocks simply because it's the only game I know that's all about sex and cannibalism.

item.name: Stack Market
item.comment: It's a really good idea to mix strategy with dexterity, but for some reason, it doesn't work in this incarnation -- something lively is missing that makes this game fall flat.

item.name: Star Hop: Game of the Cosmos
item.comment: Much harder than Space Hop. Fond memories; bad game.

item.name: Star Trek: Expeditions
item.comment: The mechanics and theme fit really well together, and the whole is pretty much intuitive. I'm afraid the game may start feeling samey, but expansions could fix that.

item.name: Star Wars: Epic Duels
item.comment: Perfectly stupid fun. It's all theme, so don't go in expecting anything too brain-burning.

item.name: Sternenhimmel
item.comment: Really interesting blind bidding area majority game, with the intriguing mechanism that most often it is bet to be second rather than first.

item.name: Stick Around
item.comment: I actually like this better than Travel Blokus. It's quicker and I can prove that the first player doesn't always win.

item.name: Stonehenge
item.comment: My copy is home-made. Would love to find a professional copy, though.

item.name: Stratego
item.comment: Classic bluff and deduction game and arguably the forerunner to all those block wargames out there that everyone thinks are so nifty.

item.name: The Strategy Game
item.comment: You should be aware that this game is an unlicenced version of Blokus. I rate it an 8 because I rate Blokus an 8. However, I find it absolutely reprehensible that the producers of this game are reproducing it without the permission of the original designers.

item.name: Stronghold
item.comment: I really like the mechanism whereby the attacker's actions cost time which gives the defender resources to work with. Not sure the whole game really gels around it though.

item.name: Such a Thing?
item.comment: Interesting creativity exercise. The players build up an increasingly implausible set of adjectivial phrases until someone declares that such a thing cannot exist. Then the last to play has to come up with such a thing. It's the creative writer's equivalent of Perudo.

item.name: Super Showdown
item.comment: These rules are a mess for such a simple game: if x is the case, then y happens, UNLESS z also happens, in which case a is the result... UNLESS b also happens, in which case the original result stands. Basically it's a card bluffing game with complicated chrome.

item.name: Supremacy
item.comment: All my games of this end up in a global economic depression, and, you know, depression's just not fun.
item.conditiontext: Wear on the box, but otherwise good condition

item.name: Survive!
item.comment: There's something incredibly satisfying about gulping down your opponent's boat with a wayward sea serpent.

item.name: Taboo
item.comment: Great game for medium and advanced learners of a foreign language, because it's all about figuring out how to describe something with a limited vocabulary.

item.name: Take it Easy!
item.comment: I found my copy in Turkey, of all places!

item.name: Tako Judo
item.comment: A lot longer and heavier than I thought it would be. Not that it's bad, but it is definitely slow and ponderous. Quoth David: "My first time being an octopus is kinda depressing."

item.name: Talisman
item.comment: Gets some credit for the cool theme, but the lack of character balance, the interminable playtime, and the high random element really make this game unpleasant at best

item.name: TAMSK
item.comment: This was a really cool experience, but then the game just sort of ended. I looked at my opponent and said, "Uh, I guess that's it." Really anticlimactic.

item.name: Targui
item.comment: A good abstracted wargame with a cool, unusual, and very fitting theme. The randomness in this puts it a step above a game like Risk, but also makes for an unpredictable game length.

item.name: Tempus
item.comment: It's a fairly interesting little game, but it took a bit too long for what it was.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment: Oddly reminiscent of Hansa -- it's a bit too long and too random for me to really love it, but it's still fairly good.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
Through the Desert
item.comment: I appreciate that this is elegant and simple, but it's really dry, and I'm usually tolerant of dryness. for whatever reason, I'm rarely inspired by this one, but I'm nonetheless willing to play it.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment: Perfectly fine. Feels like a lot of solitaire, but actually has some subtle player interaction.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: Nothing too special, but a perfectly fine game to play with new gamers.

item.name: Tigo
item.comment: How do the tigers win? If I or anyone I play with could win with the tigers, my rating would go way up.

item.name: Timbuktu
item.comment: How can I think while my brains are burning? This is a tough deduction game, in a similar vein to Sleuth. Sleuth is more elegant, of course, but whereas in Sleuth, one person's error can mess up the game for everyone, Timbuktu only lets you mess things up for yourself.

item.name: Titan
item.comment: Titan is by no means a perfect game in terms of design, but it is a rollicking good time despite its flaws, and that makes it incredibly enduring. It's amazingly fun even when I'm losing, and it's satisfying to recruit bigger and better monsters or to mercilessly smash a wayward company. Great stuff.
item.wantpartslist: Red torch legion from Avalon Hill version

item.name: Titan: The Arena
item.comment: This is an excellent betting game with a lot of tactics and a moderate amount of medium-term strategy. There's just enough unpredictability to keep the game lively, but enough control that the players can plan effectively. It only misses the ten because it doesn't scale particularly well -- a two-player game takes a while to get interesting whereas a five-player game is far too chaotic.

item.name: Title Bout
item.comment: It's not a game. It's watching pachinko. No decisions, no interaction, no game.

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment: Perfectly serviceable luck management game. I'd not want to play this one with more than three people -- it would bog down greatly.

item.name: Tongiaki
item.comment: This is quite good as a two-player with the rules for neutral colors. There's a bit of chaos, but it's not unmanageable: trying to predict and outsmart the chaos makes a good part of the fun. The three-player game was oddly lacking -- have to try that again.

item.name: Tortuga
item.comment: Good quick tactical abstract greatly enhanced by cute turtle pieces

item.name: Toscana
item.comment: This has a surprisingly tight economic system to it.

item.name: TransAmerica
item.comment: I felt this was overall pretty mindless with a few decisions to rouse one out of one's zombie-like reflexive game-play. But, it's harmless and quick, so what harm is there?

item.name: Trivial Pursuit
item.comment: Nothing wrong with the idea of this game. Problem is that some questions are outdated and the answers to others are just flat out wrong. Sometimes the questions are even wrong, like asking which strait connects the Black Sea to the Mediterranean.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: Bet You Know It
Troia
item.comment: More experience than game, and proof to me, at least, that archaeology is a lot of tedium with little payoff.

item.name: Trump: The Game
item.comment: Way too high in variance. However, the game should be fixable with some tweaking of how many of each card are in the deck.

item.name: Tsuro of the Seas
item.comment: The new dragon rules make take what is already a mediocre game and make it utterly chaotic. This is a penalty version in that the added rules degrade the game rather than improve it.

item.name: Tuf
item.comment: Ow ow ow... pain in my brainpan! It's a good game but the pain coutnerbalances the fun.

item.name: Tuf-abet
item.comment: Pretty uninspiring as word games go.
item.conditiontext: Traded for Silk Road

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment: This is a really strong immersive experience that gets deeper with every play. It's a constant struggle of crisis management, the key to which is squeezing benefits out of the cards when offered opportunities. That said, the game can feel very claustrophopbic when the cards are against you, and that can get frustrating at times.

item.name: Twixt
item.comment: I think I need to play a lot more of this to really understand it.

item.name: Tyros
item.conditiontext: Banished to Tartarus in exchange for Gipsy King

item.name: Ubi
item.comment: The way the questions are written -- I think it's English words in the order of Latin grammar -- really detracts from what is otherwise a difficult, if uninspiring, geography trivia game.

item.name: Union Pacific
item.comment: Nearly-perfect stck investment game. I just wish I could buy things with the money I earn; like, maybe buy another draw from the available stocks.

item.name: UNO
item.comment: Mindless, but mostly harmless.

item.name: Upwords
item.comment: I remember this feeling very constrictive and dull

item.name: UR
item.comment: A pleasant surprise. It's got a good combination of planning ahead and turn-solving. Perhaps it moves a bit slowly, but it nonetheless feels intuitive.

item.name: Ursuppe
item.comment: Ah, the game of eating and excreting.

item.name: Vanuatu
item.comment: Very tight, very nasty, very entertaining game. The bidding mechanism for available actions is novel and well-designed.

item.name: Vasco da Gama
item.comment: First game mind-boggling. More later.

item.name: Vegas Showdown
item.comment: Showdown is a bit of a misnomer. A Vegas Showdown would have something to do with playing cards, or a roulette wheel, or at least a Carol Channing-Phyllis Diller center-stage cage match. But this is about interior designers fitting out casinos. It's got an OK auction mechanic saddled onto a space management superstructure.

item.name: Vertigo
item.comment: Gravity is a harsh mistress. See, sometimes the tokens don't fall the way they "should," and sometimes, there's a 50-50 chance that the token will fall one or the other way. Still, this is fun and really cool-looking, but I find the uncertainty makes it lose some of its charm.

item.name: Warhamster Rally
item.comment: A flawed attempt to improve on the programmed-move mechanism.

item.name: Warp 6
item.comment: Cool little tactical game. It's got just enough chance in it to give it some flavor.

item.name: Wayfinder
item.comment: A nice, but non-functional board. Rules that are very poorly written. Long, frustrating play that seems to prevent strategy-building. Arbitrary rules (five second rule?!) kludged on to patch over the game's serious faults, including cumbersome number problems and a tendency toward overanalysis. All in all a most painful experience.

item.name: Die Weinh√§ndler
item.comment: An atrocity of a game

item.name: When Darkness Comes
item.comment: The system for this is annoying -- fiddly, unintuitive, involves lots of looking stuff up. It may be better as a campaign-type game, but really, if I'm going to devote time to a campaign, it'll be a full-blown RPG.
item.conditiontext: Partially punched, but in good condition

item.name: Winner's Circle
item.comment: The game changes significantly depending on how many people are playing. In a six-player game, low variance horses tend to do better, whereas in a two-player game, high-variance horses are more attractive bets. It's a clever design, though -- simple, but intriguing, and appealing to players of all skill levels.

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment: A trivia game that can be played by those who don't like trivia. Some people know stuff. Other people know who knows stuff. And some people know the odds. This game can reward all three equally.

item.name: Wizard
item.comment: Oh Hell is ok. Add in four ubertrumpen and untertrumpen and suddenly you have a much more interesting game. Also, adding eight cards makes the deck evenly divisible by 3, 4, 5, and 6! Magic!

item.name: wordXchange
item.comment: Inferior to Snatch. Do you really need wildcards in this sort of game? And shouldn't you be allowed to grab your own words?

item.name: The World Cup Game
item.comment: Played the Uruguay board -- seemed a bit scripted (Urugay walked away with the game) but fun. The larger board felt less scripted, but it took so incredibly long.

item.name: World of Warcraft Trading Card Game
item.comment: Certainly nothing wrong with it, but it feels slow. It also is not as rich an experience as is Magic. The team-play scenarios, however, are a cool idea.

item.name: The Wrong Game
item.comment: There's a psychological phenomenon at work here: it's very hard to say something deliberately wrong quickly. But it's not really something worth sculpting a whole game around.

item.name: Xe Queo!
item.comment: My version is homemade.

item.name: Ys
item.comment: This game is soulless. It's clinical, precise, and dry. Which isn't to say it's bad -- on the contrary, it's rather good. Just don't expect it to be exciting.

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment: Appears to be best with three players. The more I play it, the more I like it, but I sure as heck don't understand it.

item.name: Z√àRTZ
item.comment: This is a nailbiter abstract. You'll be setting something up, knowing that your opponent can use the same setup against you if he's clever enough, and hoping he's not. Finding the gambits to force a gain for yourself is mind-twisting fun.

item.name: Zhadu: Legend of the Sharing
item.comment: Zhadu is elegant; it feels as ancient as mancala or backgammon. The rules are simple, the game-play intricate and subtle, and the play-time quick. On top of that, the game just LOOKS cool. Great stuff.

item.name: Ziggurat
item.comment: This is a fairly clever little game. Nothing incredibly special, but intuitive, easy, but still fairly challenging

item.name: Zitternix
item.comment: Not bad at all when slightly adultified

item.name: Zombies!!!
item.comment: Good for Halloween

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: Coloretto is an excellent game and needlessly monkeying with its elegance has produced a lifeless game that feels unpleasantly arbitrary.

item.name: Zoowaboo
item.comment: Cute bidding game involving spatial relations.
